police.title: Police Stops and Searches
police.response: If they don‚Äôt have a warrant or your permission, they generally can‚Äôt search your phone or belongings. But there are exceptions.
details: During a stop, you can ask: 'Am I being detained, or am I free to go?' If you‚Äôre not being detained, you can leave. Stay calm and respectful.
Officers can perform a frisk if they suspect you‚Äôre armed, but a full search usually requires probable cause or consent.
Never physically resist, even if you believe your rights are being violated. Assert them verbally and remember everything for later documentation.
dos: Ask if you're free to leave
tips: Record the interaction if safe to do so.
Write down badge numbers and names afterward.
Ask if you're under arrest before answering questions.

related.question: Can police search my car during a traffic stop?
related.answer: Only if they have probable cause, your consent, or see something in plain view.

related.question: What if they say they smell weed?
related.answer: That may qualify as probable cause in many states. Stay silent and calm.

immigration.title: Immigration and ICE
immigration.response: You do not have to open your door unless ICE has a warrant signed by a judge. You have the right to remain silent.
details: ICE agents often rely on fear. Stay calm. You can ask for the warrant to be slipped under the door. If it‚Äôs not signed by a judge, you don‚Äôt have to comply.
You can say: 'I do not wish to speak without a lawyer.' You do not have to tell them your immigration status.
Even if you're undocumented, you have constitutional rights. Do not sign any documents without understanding them.
donts: Don‚Äôt sign anything without a lawyer
tips: Create a safety plan with your family if ICE comes.

related.question: What if they come to my job?
related.answer: Same rules apply. You can ask if you're free to leave and stay silent.

related.question: What if I already have a deportation order?
related.answer: Call a lawyer immediately. You may still have options under new rulings.

housing.title: Tenant & Housing Rights
housing.response: Landlords cannot enter your home without proper notice or legal cause. You have protections against unfair evictions.
details: In most places, landlords must give written notice (typically 24‚Äì48 hours) before entering your unit unless there's an emergency.
Evictions require a formal court process. You can't be kicked out just because a landlord wants you gone quickly.
You are entitled to a safe and livable home. If essential repairs are ignored, legal remedies may apply‚Äîbut consult a tenant organization first.
donts: Don‚Äôt withhold rent without legal advice
tips: Take timestamped photos of any issues.
Save every text, email, or voicemail.
Check if your city has rent stabilization or tenant unions.

related.question: Can they evict me for reporting them?
related.answer: That may be illegal retaliation. Report it to a tenant rights group or housing board.

related.question: What if I have no written lease?
related.answer: You may still have rights under 'implied tenancy' laws depending on your state.

protest.title: Protesting & Free Speech
protest.response: You have the right to protest peacefully in public spaces. Police can‚Äôt arrest you for filming or expressing your views.
details: You can protest on sidewalks, parks, or other public forums without a permit‚Äîas long as you're not blocking traffic.
Recording police is legal in all 50 states, but don‚Äôt interfere physically.
Private businesses can ask you to leave. If you don‚Äôt, they can call police for trespassing.
dos: Stay on sidewalks or public spaces
donts: Don‚Äôt block traffic without a permit
tips: Carry a paper copy of emergency contacts and a legal aid number.
Use chalk or signs‚Äîspray paint or property damage is not protected speech.
Designate a trusted contact in case you‚Äôre detained.

related.question: Can schools discipline me for protesting?
related.answer: Public schools can't punish you just for speech‚Äîunless it's disruptive to learning.

related.question: Can I wear protest shirts at work?
related.answer: That depends on your employer and whether it interferes with operations.

work.title: Workplace & Labor Rights
work.response: You have the right to fair pay, safe conditions, and to speak up without retaliation‚Äîdepending on your employment status.
details: Federal and state laws protect your right to a safe workplace, minimum wage, and overtime pay‚Äîeven if you're undocumented.
You may have the right to organize with coworkers about pay or conditions. This is protected by the National Labor Relations Act.
Discrimination based on race, gender, disability, or religion is illegal‚Äîdocument everything and report to HR or the EEOC.
dos: Know your wage and hour rights
donts: Don‚Äôt quit without checking your rights
Don‚Äôt assume you have no recourse
tips: Save copies of paystubs, schedules, and written warnings.

related.question: What if I'm undocumented?

school.title: Student & School Rights
school.response: Public school students still have free speech rights, but schools can set limits to maintain order.
details: You can speak your mind as long as it doesn‚Äôt cause a disruption to learning or threaten others.
Schools can‚Äôt search your belongings without 'reasonable suspicion,' but they don‚Äôt need a warrant like police do.

Don‚Äôt forget that school rules vary
tips: Keep a record of incidents, emails, or punishments.
You can usually bring a parent or advocate to school meetings.

related.question: Can they suspend me for protesting?
related.answer: Not if you're peaceful and not disrupting class. But they may discipline for cutting class.

related.question: Do LGBTQ+ students have protections?
related.answer: Yes. Harassment based on gender identity or sexual orientation is prohibited in many states.
